title: When will Canada next permit discretionary travel for foreign nationals arriving from the United States?
preds: A final comment on this question. ‘Canada and the United States have agreed to extend the ban on nonessential travel between the United States and Canada through June 21, 2021.’ https://thepointsguy.com/guide/is-canada-open-for-travel/

Updating from 0/0/0/4/96 due to the closure being extended beyond 1 June. Leaving 1% for the possibility that in the next 10 days they resolve to allow vaccinated people through. (Even 1% seems high.)
The slight chance I was holding out for is gone: https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/canada-u-s-border-restrictions-extended-another-month-to-june-21-1.5433345
They haven’t done it yet and time is running out. The high vaccine hesitancy in the US doesn’t help either.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-05-14/trudeau-government-begins-work-on-reopening-u-s-canada-border They're allegedly working on reopening it but its not even in the publicly announced stage. 2 weeks left in the question, and an announcement of a future reopening wouldn't count, highly unlikely.

It's an outside chance, but with vaccinations picking up, I think there is a slight chance of something like a vaccine passport happening before time runs out for this question: https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/vaccinations-are-picking-up-is-it-time-to-reopen-the-us-canada-border

The recent change in CDC protocols and the accelerated pullback on mandates across the world makes me hesitate now. The timeline is short, but a discretionary permit finding its way into the next update seems more plausible today.

https://orders-in-council.canada.ca/attachment.php?attach=40498&lang=en
Latest prohibition order continues the ban until 21 may.  So expect a revision / extension then.  So potentially a vaccine related exemption could come in then, in time for June 1.  But seems unlikely at the moment when infection rates have not substantially  changed in either country.  What has changed to make Canada change it’s rule?

Beside US political pressures from Schumer, i would be very surprised if Ottawa authorize Americans to come when inside Canada there are restrictions between provinces. Even if vaccines operations seem to go very well, the operations for a first dose is not quite in the time frame of the the end of june. 
https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/schumer-biden-border-1.6016204
On the other side, Justin Trudeau, want to go at the G-7 in London in mid June. It would be a very bad symbolic gesture if the rest of Canadians cannot traveled, so maybe he is confident himself that a lot of Canadians will be vaccinated at this time.

To stop this covid first step is to have 70 % or more vaccinated , then entry for all tested , healed or vaccined. 
Only in 2022 ..2023 no more restrictions.
It's a long shot, but there's a slight possibility vaccinated travelers will be allowed to travel to Canada from the US later this month.
Updating from 0/0/0/8/92 due to passage of time and the extension of travel restrictions to 21 May [1]. [1] https://twitter.com/CanBorder/status/1384513527654883328
Border closed for another month. Ontario suffering from another Covid surge. Unlikely borders will open before July 1st
Extremely unlikely before June 1- mainly because Canada seems to face a second wave of Covid-19.
Adjusting towards after June 1st based on current stats and political messaging. Not going 100 yet
Looking at covid cases spiking in Canada
Updating from 0/0/0/10/90 [1] due to passage of time. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1258122

The vaccination procurement and distribution in Canada has not been particularly successful, but supply chains and cross border flows have remained intact which has allowed Canadian authorities to be in less of a hurry to lift the restrictions.
The current restrictions, reviewed on a monthly basis are currently in force until April 21.
Biden has asked for all states to be prepared to make all its people eligible to access vaccinations by May 1st. 
According to the CDC it takes at least two weeks for a covid vaccination to become effective which suggests June 1 being too early to lift restrictions.  https://thepointsguy.com/guide/is-canada-open-for-travel/  https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/eventually-but-not-for-today-trudeau-says-of-reopening-canada-u-s-border-1.5348199  https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/keythingstoknow.html
Reducing probability of this happening before 1st June as there is unlikely to be enough time for a vaccine passport system to be set up

All airline passengers to the United States ages two years and older must provide a negative COVID-19 viral test taken within three calendar days of travel. Alternatively, travelers to the U.S. may provide documentation from a licensed health care provider of having recovered from COVID-19 in the 90 days preceding travel. Land border restrictions for travel to the United States remain in effect through April 21, 2021 and may be extended.  For information on travel restrictions for Canada, see Entry and Exit Requirements below.
The current surge in Canada is going to prevent further re-openings, especially risky ones like international travel.
It is expected that most Canadians will be vaccinated by end of June, not before

Updating from 0/0/0/20/80 as we are just 2 months away from the top bucket and I doubt that's enough time to set up any kind of vaccine passport system. Most US adults will be vaccinated by 31 May, but probably a significant fraction will not (at least 10%), to say nothing of people who refuse the vaccine. So until most of Canada is vaccinated (won't happen before June), the risk to them is too great and the return too small. Basically only the tourism industry is hurting from this? And that's not one of the major industries there. I've read that even with pre-flight testing, they are still getting ~1% of passengers landing in Canada with covid. So it that makes it less likely that Canada would open up to non-essential travel by requiring tests and quarantines and so on.

Canada will require proof of vaccination. A formal system needs putting in place. It takes time to do that, and won't happen within the next two months. However, discretionary relaxation would be possible and might be quickly put in place at the border.
Canada has smart people running the country.
Cases are increasing again in Canada in what could be the start of a third wave.  It will take some time to bring it back under control.  Reducing to zero probability for prior to 1 June.

Latest Govt announcement, confirming the kind of distance this question’s resolution is looking at, https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/eventually-but-not-for-today-trudeau-says-of-reopening-canada-u-s-border-1.5348199

https://ca.travelpulse.com/news/impacting-travel/trudeau-government-says-vaccine-passports-could-work.html Only 30% because I don't have much confidence in how quickly diplomatic gears could turn in North America, but I see it happening rather soon, 31st May is just a tough deadline.

Not enough is going to change before June 1. There's so much coronavirus spread in the US, and barely a majority of the US population has some level of immunity to the virus. I think they'll expect that people willing to travel might be less likely to be vaccinated as well. And then they're having their own problems with virus spread, too. I think they'll wait.
Update 4/17: Restrictions likely to continue. Currently, no exceptions for vaccinated travelers, either.
https://www.ifallsjournal.com/news/public_safety/canada-border-closure-extension-expected/article_6aa78a41-f618-5725-bcc6-eab1ed6a5b7a.html
Update 4/27: Restrictions in place through May 21. However, Canadian government officials have been looking into vaccine verification for incoming travelers. Could such a program be implemented before June 1? That's somewhat hard to picture. By July 1, probably. But it's not clear to me that vaccine certificates could be implemented in the next 5 weeks. I would think they would give people some notice before any such change took effect, too. Could they make such changes effective on May 21? Not sure.
https://www.skyscanner.ca/tips-and-inspiration/covid-vaccine-certificate
https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/trudeau-covid-19-vaccine-passports-1.5947624#:~:text=Dominic%20LeBlanc%2C%20the%20minister%20of,worldwide%20in%20the%20coming%20months. Update 5/9: The only question in my mind was whether Canada might possibly start to accept some sort of vaccine passport before the end of the month, but it seemed extremely unlikely. Trudeau has said on April 29 that Canada isn't ready for these yet: "whether Canada will only reopen its borders to vaccinated foreign nationals remain questions the federal government says it’s not ready to answer." So I just can't picture this happening before June 1.
https://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/vaccine-passports-to-be-expected-but-canada-not-ready-to-set-terms-yet-trudeau-1.5404349 Update 5/19: Trudeau is saying 75% of all Canadians should be vaccinated before the US border can be opened. That seems a little unrealistic; I would be surprised if 75% will ever be vaccinated.
https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-news-today-all-adults-in-ontario-now-eligible-to-book-vaccine/

There is going to have a bit post-spring break spike in infection rates with increasing proportions of variant infections.  Also, with some of the US states opening wide up, Cdn gen pop won't want the border wide open.

Rising case numbers likely to lead to more restrictions rather than less. https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=310..latest&pickerSort=desc&pickerMetric=total_cases&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~CAN
Updating from 0/0/1/25/74 because clearly it's not going to happen in March. Moving some mass up until I have time to think about this properly. Great points by @slapthepancake and @Francis_Urquhart.
Forecasters tend more and more towards this choice since the beginning of January 2021.

Trudeau’s comments over the weekend seem definitive on no discretionary travel in April or May, and perhaps not till September.[1] [1] https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/vaccine-and-case-counts-will-determine-when-border-opens-says-trudeau-1.5344805

Trudeau is not falling to pressure from US to open border. He will continue to review/extend closures month-by-month according to latest: https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/vaccine-and-case-counts-will-determine-when-border-opens-says-trudeau-1.5344805

The realistic scenario for this happening is allowing vaccinated individuals to travel. Thus far the resistance to a vaccine passport program has been concerns about equity and about asymptomatic transmission. Results of a study out of Israel a few days ago however reported the Pfizer vaccine reduced asymptomatic transmission by 90+%, though the study isn't peer-reviewed, which mitigates one of the barriers to discretionary travel.  Still not very likely, since the EU has said vaccine passports would take about 3 months to roll out and we haven't even started in the US, Canada's vaccine rollout has been woefully slow, their COVID cases have plateaued and stopped decreasing, and the other vaccines (especially J&J) haven't been studied for asymptomatic transmission yet. It would be a very quick timeline, and it would be a bad look for the Canadian government to be allowing obnoxious American tourists to come into the country while their own citizens are unable to get vaccinated. There's still the ethical issues surrounding vaccine passports that the Biden administration will probably not want to deal with. There's the issue of travel to Canada from the US meaning that money will be spent at non-American businesses, which the US may not want to promote by cooperating on a vaccine passport. Lastly, this has underpinned all of my forecasts, but everything in COVID takes longer than expected.  Canada also recently tightened its border travel restrictions (https://www.startribune.com/cancel-your-vacation-plans-canada-tightening-border-rules-amid-covid-19-pandemic/600023390/), which is going in the opposite direction of what you'd want for even a selective reopening. Even the Tourism Industry Association of Canada isn't pushing for a reopening of international travel, just a roadmap to do so in the future, most likely because they don't think travel will recover till 2026 so rushing is not as helpful as it may seem. They also mention that the Canadian government has been very clear that they want to promote regional travel within Canada before they promote international travel, and they are yet to take that step. (https://a628df72-7108-47d6-9152-562f641e49d8.filesusr.com/ugd/aa4fa6_f60a2b8f6712490ca5b711f88c42c295.pdf) (or google "2021 TIAC Tourism Recovery Plan" if you don't like weird links). Canadians spend more abroad than foreigners spend in Canada for tourism, so the financial incentive for international reopening isn't strong either.  It's genuinely difficult to find a yes case for a reopening. Maybe as a gesture to the US? There's too much going in the opposite direction for that to be realistic. Maybe if they can allow foreigners in but not Canadians out? Can't imagine how that would be justified to a public upset with their vaccine rollout.

Provincial Health Officer Dr. Bonnie Henry has suggested B.C. will be in a better position in the summer as vaccinations continue, yet Halford doesn’t think anything should change with the border until there is scientific data supporting the choice.     Trudeau has stated that border will remain closed https://buffalonews.com/news/local/trudeau-canadian-u-s-border-to-remain-closed-for-now-to-keep-safe/article_f3ff5ba6-792b-11eb-b34a-877555cf01e5.html

Updating from 0/0/1/39/60 [1] due to passage of time, and great point by @Mark_T about it being best for Canada to have tight restrictions now, in order to have a higher chance of being able to lift them in the summer. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1227609
Wild cards accounted for and probability reduced a little after a good overconfidence shaming from @pietrokc.
bucket 4 reduced to 5 from 15,  10 added to bucket 5

Building on the excellent analysis of @Mark_T and following the certainty expressed in the latest forecast from @SE_Meyer, whom I have learned to ignore at peril to my Brier score, I am moving up my estimate to 100% “not before June 1.”  As of March 5, Canada has fully vaccinated just 1.5% of their population.[1]  Canada’s problems with getting enough vaccine have meant they need to draw on their COVAX allotment, even though that means taking vaccine meant for poor countries and will still have only 8 million doses by the end of March.[2]  The unreliability of supply has caused the government to continue with its September timeline for “delivering vaccines to all Canadians who want them.”  Even if you believe they are underpromsing to overdeliver, this is not a country that is going to welcome discretionary visitors from the U.S. before June 1.   Canadian public health officials can read the same NYT and WaPo stories we do about CDC concerns over a fourth wave in the next four months due to the plateau of new daily cases and the removal of mask mandates in Texas and Mississippi, and California allowing theme parks to open and spectators at Major League Baseball.[3] Canada’s PM and health minister have way more pressing matters on their agenda before June than when they will allow Texans to visit for hunting and fishing trips. [1] https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-tracker-canada-latest-numbers-explainer/
[2] https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/covax-anand-vaccine-timetable-1.5939270
[3] https://www.npr.org/2021/03/03/973286247/now-is-not-the-time-to-stop-wearing-a-mask-says-cdc-director-rochelle-walensky
Adjusting towards long term... I could also see the USA holding the border closed depemding on Canada's ability to vaccinate.

Updated based on vaccine announcements from US and Canadian governments. https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/canada-s-covid-19-cases-start-to-climb-as-variants-spread-in-step-with-dire-forecasts-1.5330437

Canada to provide swab tests at border, extends border closure to the US through at least March 21
https://thepointsguy.com/guide/is-canada-open-for-travel/  Trudeau announced that travelers entering via a land border will be required to produce the result of a negative COVID-19 PCR test. People who fail to do so could be fined up to $2,370. This requirement went into effect on Feb. 15.
In early February, Canada extended its ban on cruise ships, prohibiting vessels carrying 100 or more people until Feb. 28, 2022. The ban also effectively closes the Canadian Arctic to boat-related tourism until 2022 and puts the entire Alaska cruise season in jeopardy.

My only confusion on this one is what if Canada reinstates discretionary travel for only those who have received a vaccine? My current forecast does not consider this scenario as causing the question to resolve

Vaccinations in Canada are picking up momentum but still only 3%.  
Unlikely that border measures are changes until there is a significant percentage of the Canadian population that is vaccinated.  This will not happen until mid-summer.
Issue was not raised in bilateral meeting between Canadian PM and US President this week.

Uptick in case numbers in urban provinces [1], combined with new variant "third waves" fears [2] seem likely to encourage an increase in restrictions and containment measures rather than a decrease, at least over the term of this question. Bounds of this question are contained to US points of entry which narrows the criteria somewhat, but without a robust list of US travel restrictions and/or track and trace programme in place it seems unlikely Canada will be comfortable lifting controls on this potential "backdoor" for new variants to make their way into the population. Peak season for tourism in Canada is end of June / July to  September [3] so there seems much less economic pressure to lift restrictions on non-discretionary travel before this time.  In fact it could be argued that it's in Canada's interests to keep controls in place right up to this point to give the best chance of being able to safely and justifiably lift them during peak season. [1] https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-11-15..latest&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
[2] https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/this-isn-t-a-wave-it-s-a-forest-fire-experts-predict-rise-of-covid-19-variant-cases-in-canada-1.5307870
[3] https://www.tripsavvy.com/when-to-go-to-canada-1481671#:~:text=Peak%20season%20in%20Canada%20typically,schools%20are%20out%20of%20session.
Rise in cases in BC seems to show how fragile the situation is right now and how quickly things can turn around. https://bc.ctvnews.ca/video?clipId=1993890

Borders are still closed. January 2021 saw increased restrictions on those Canadians driving across from US to Canada. Number of vaccines received improving but not optimized for cross country vaccinations. US is still slow on the uptake for opening vaccinations up to the general public.

Vaccination rates in Canada continue to lag USA.   Politics of travel during COVID-19 pandemic in Canada also continue to support the current approach to the US border until conditions change on both sides of the border.  Difficult to see how this will be true before summer 2021 at the earliest.

Americans are getting vaccinated and cold/flu season is fully underway. As more Americans become protected and other cheaper vaccine options enter the market discretionary travel should help Canada’s hurting tourism economy ahead of peak summer travel season.

Staying ahead of the crowd on this one with the Canadian vaccine rollout programme going slowly and with new travel restrictions kicking in over the last week: https://www.cbc.ca/news/health/canada-slow-vaccine-rollout-covid-19-1.5862358
https://www.forbes.com/sites/sandramacgregor/2021/02/01/canada-introduces-more-restrictions-on-international-travel/ Also noting that Canada’s peak season for tourism is July - October, meaning less commercial, financial and economic pressures to open up early (and far more incentive to keep controls in place up to then to give vaccines and virus control the best chance of setting the conditions for a potential peak season reopening). .https://www.authentikcanada.com/gb-en/faq/when-to-visit-canada Canada (and hopefully the world) will have learnt lessons from the UK’s politically and economically motivated “short term gain, long term pain” missteps in handling the virus and the comparatively disastrous fatality rate it resulted in. https://warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/economics/research/centres/cage/news/30-10-20-eat_out_to_help_out_scheme_drove_new_covid_19_infections_up_by_between_8_and_17_new_research_finds/

Realigning slightly based on improved optimism with US vaccination programme and steadily dropping case rates for both Canada and the US. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=CAN~USA&region=World&vaccinationsMetric=true&interval=total&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc

Updating from 0/0/5/30/65 [1]. Extra restrictions on the border recently imposed make Feb-Mar even less likely. But falling US cases make it a bit more likely earlier than June. Also the extra measures may allow them to technically open the border to discretionary travel from the US, while still requiring so much of travelers (quarantine, etc) that effectively very few choose to go. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1204243

New travel restrictions, the threat of new variants and the worldwide progress of vaccination all seem to point to a slow and cautious reopening of discretionary travel (the lowest priority reasoning from a public health perspective). https://www.narcity.com/en-ca/travel/canadas-travel-rules-have-had-a-major-update-heres-everything-you-need-to-know

Even more restrictions put in place. The new variants may delay the reopening of the borders [1] [1] https://www.narcity.com/en-ca/travel/canadas-travel-rules-have-had-a-major-update-heres-everything-you-need-to-know

New travel restrictions imply CAN Govt intend to continue to with the strategy of caution and containment in the face of current and growing potential for import of new and more transmissible variants. Unknowns in vaccine efficacy vs new variants adds unknowns to CAN and US vaccine programme progress, meaning discretionary travel restrictions seem likely to remain in place whilst government aid programmes can mitigate the financial impact and he virus spread remains the most pressing concern for both sides. https://www.cicnews.com/2021/01/canada-announces-new-restrictions-for-travellers-0116997.html#gs.s7yukp
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jan/29/canada-air-passengers-quarantine-hotel-coronavirus
Additional restrictions on travel announced today by PM Trudeau.  Travel restrictions becoming increasingly political issue.

Slight adjustment based on this Reuters update on Canada's vaccination programme progress and Trudeau's potential travel restrictions (used in this forecast as an indicator of Canada's general comfort levels with discretionary travel). 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-canada-idUSKBN29R24N?taid=600b188dc8ffe70001f64cda&utm_campaign=trueAnthem:+Trending+Content&utm_medium=trueAnthem&utm_source=twitter Pressure from influential Quebec to maintain (and enhance) travel limitations :
https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/quebec-premier-asks-trudeau-to-ban-all-non-essential-travel-from-canada-1.5273111 Also accommodating new, more transmissible variants that will increase international caution in allowing discretionary travel whilst vaccination programmes worldwide find their feet (Q3 / 4 2021 earliest).

More political pressures to restrict travel.
https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/quebec-premier-asks-trudeau-to-ban-all-non-essential-travel-from-canada-1.5273111

US case load only getting worse since last forecast. Big unknown now is whether vaccination record will permit immunized individuals to travel a bit earlier. Depends on data to be accumulated on effect of vaccine on vector potential.

Forecast based on an assumption that the Canadian government will be looking for reasons to open up the lucrative tourism trade from the US when conditions (infection rates and vaccination roll outs) can be seen as "balanced" / close to in parity across both countries. To be reviewed based on the performance of the Biden administrations recently published vaccination goals for the US population. https://tiac-aitc.ca/_Impact_on_Tourism.html
https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/dec/08/joe-biden-coronavirus-vaccine-health-team
https://edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-pandemic-vaccine-updates-01-15-21/h_700d1390e79ef2a34f3d30ccf0fb4dd3

Decreasing Feb-March and increasing the later two buckets. No news on this that I can see and probably still depends on relative cases. Likely still a month or two before this current wave has ended and cases have dropped significantly in the US.

I note the question concerns foreign nationals entering Canada from the US rather than just US citizens/residents. I am assuming this is about border controls only.
The issue here is the disparity between the Canadian and US health systems. Canada has a universal health system based on need rather ability to pay. As we are aware the US system is State based, private and based on the ability to pay. A universal system is considered as a part of a  socialist doctrine which is an anathema to Americans.
This has created an inability to handle the pandemic in the US as opposed to the Canadian model. The Canadians do not want to overwhelm their hospital system with importing further problems from the US, where the pandemic is out of control. Vaccinations will take at leats until the second quarter to have an effect. https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/local/2021/01/12/canada-extends-us-border-closure-through-feb-21-2021/  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html  https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/  https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/canada/  https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(18)30181-8/fulltext  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3633404/

Political scandals related to discretionary travel over the Holidays makes this decision more complex.  Continued worsening of COVID-19 in both countries will slow the timeline and pending arrival of new US Administration is something to watch in the coming weeks.

The roll-out of the vaccine in the U.S. is going slower than expected even though the U.S. has bought a huge amount of the available and expected production of vaccines. The roll-out in Canada is going well, timely, but they have a different priority list than many U.S. states. They are vaccinating older people more than the U.S. is currently, which means the general population is farther down the priority list. So U.S. general pop. still constitutes a sizable risk group for Canadian gen. pop. Est. timeline for U.S. gen. pop. to get vaccine is end of summer 2021 now, so I think Canada will push opening borders for leisure travel until late summer 2021 at least. If roll-out in U.S. picks up speed that timeline may shift back to May timeframe again. Canada benefits economically from travel by U.S. gen. pop.

Not more than 115 000 vaccines dose have been delivered in Quebec, most affected by the covid-19.

There is pressures from Ottawa, and pharma to give double dose, so there is less than 1% of the population that get vaccine.

“We could be vaccinating four times more people than we do right now, but we don't have enough doses,” he said."

Canada is struggling with containing COVID by their own metrics (not nearly as bad as the US). Canadian Federal government has been strong on the border issue, I don't see a Biden administration pushing too hard on re-opening borders soon, they have enough on their plate as is. People that have to seem to be able to permeate the borders with little issue.

Latest restrictions extended until 1/21, giving the Biden admin a chance to possibly open talks with Canada. However, giving rising numbers in both countries, it appears unlikely the talks will move quickly. There is also falling confidence among Canadians about permitting U.S. travel.  We are likely looking at a Q2 or later decision.

+ 5 Between 1 April 2021 and 31 March 2021 USA side Fauci:
"Priority groups should receive a vaccine between now and March, and April will be “open season” where anybody who wants to receive a vaccine can get one, he said." https://www.webmd.com/lung/news/20201223/fauci-umbrella-of-protection-possible-by-summer
Not as long as COVID is spiking in the U.S., and U.S. citizens are continuing to refuse to follow public health guidelines!

Canadian winters are harsh so I doubt there is much demand in the US for tourism in Canada before April. Which means Canadians in the tourist business would not heavily lobby for it, and in fact their business models already account for this. I think April 2021 is also too soon in terms of how many people will be vaccinated by then, and what the US covid numbers will look like. I'm allotting 30% mainly for late May 2021.
There is no reason to risk it for low demand. Discretionary travel would likely go to primarily Toronto and Montreal, highly dense areas where the virus is more likely to spread.

If Canada makes an exception for people who can prove they’ve been vaccinated prior to entry, I assume that counts as a “yes.” I’m thinking about my friends up in Point Roberts, Washington, and noting that opening 1 port of entry counts, when considering how to forecast this question.
https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/point-roberts-covid-1.5740806

Maybe vaccin will come sooner than expected.
https://ca.news.yahoo.com/quebec-reports-1-577-covid-165820941.html
The cases in US will drop below reasonable level only in Feb-Mar time frame. Moving some weight from bin 3 to bin 5

It’s not clear what “a long time” means but I’ll remain heavy on the last bucket.
https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/trudeau-indicates-canada-u-s-border-restrictions-to-last-a-long-time

I think this really depends on when vaccination begins to take effect - once enough people are vaccinated, the infection rates should start to drop exponentially. Allowing for logistics of distribution, I guess we might be at 50% vaccination sometime around March, give or take a month. Also assuming some people will maintain some social distancing even with the vaccine, this should put r0 below 1 some time in this time frame. At that point it's a question of how fast the curve drops off and how much political will there is to reopen borders.

Considering how public health officials have managed this situation thus far, the decision would be made based on the status of the outbreak. Travel restrictions were one of the first measures taken, and rolling them back has never been seriously discussed at any point since they started in March, leading me to believe that the outbreak will have to be at a very low and stable level before the restriction is lifted. The restriction has been renewed every 30 days on the 21st of the month without much fuss. I also focus on the US, since the decision to allow Americans into Canada will rest more on the status of our outbreak, which has been consistently worse anyways.  The only way that a low and stable case load happens is with a vaccine, thus probabilities almost solely rest on predicting how a vaccine rollout will take place, and what effects it will have. Dr. Fauci estimated that vaccines could start reaching everyday Americans, i.e. the type who would be traveling, “as early as April and through July”, so that's probably the most optimistic timeline assuming everything else goes smoothly. Before this point, essential workers and people like schoolteachers and food service workers would receive it as well. In that ideal world, vaccines would start reaching people April 1, and then the second doses would begin to be received April 21. The April renewal discussion would be then, right as the earliest people are getting their second dose, meaning that the traveling population is almost entirely unvaccinated still, making a restriction lifting highly unlikely.  The presumed next opportunity in that ideal scenario would be on May 21. A reasonable percent of the traveling population would be vaccinated at this point, in addition to a lot of people working in service sector jobs covered in earlier rollout phases. I would expect cases to be at a lower level by this point after the huge winter spike we’re experiencing. What may occur at this point is the Canadian government opens travel through one or two ports restricted to people with negative tests and recorded vaccination as a test run to see if it’s safe to do nationwide. This may lead to people swarming the border and may or may not be popular though, depending on what the case load looks like. If everything goes smoothly and the vaccines are highly effective in preventing transmission, and caseloads dramatically roll out as the vaccine is distributed and weather warms, it’s conceivable. I consider it highly unlikely for a number of reasons. Firstly, a host of factors could hinder the rollout, including: vaccine not being as effective as initially claimed in the low infection count studies, people not taking the vaccine, distribution chain failings i.e. refrigeration issues leading to lack of effectiveness, and miscellaneous supply chain issues hindering production. Further, Dr. Fauci has been very clear about the importance of maintaining public health measures even as the vaccine rollout happens, since it’s not clear how effectively it blocks all transmission. The vaccine is tested by looking at numbers of patients who develop symptoms and then test positive, not blanket testing the study groups. Its efficacy with regard to preventing asymptomatic transmission is unknown, and very important. For those reasons, I put the probability that caseloads are at a low enough level to even consider reopening in May at around 65%. Travel restrictions are also one of the easier measures to maintain politically, since they’re simple to implement, have comparatively little impact on most people’s everyday lives not near the border, and can feed off of resentment of foreigners, like Canada has had towards Americans traveling through Canada throughout the lockdown. Such a measure is likely to be a low priority for rolling back as outbreaks lessen under the vaccine, even if they would be possible. I also expect people to be less observant of guidelines as the vaccine rolls out and they consider themselves immune, which would make playing with a travel ban less likely. America’s reputation for a poor response may be the most impactful factor though. As the ban gets progressively rolled back, it’s unlikely that the US would be the first country on the list to unban for that reason. Lastly, Canada has been fairly conservative in their response to COVID, heavily deferring to public health officials, who would presumably not recommend reopening travel to a country like the US. In that ideal case scenario, the chance that Canada would be willing to experiment with a border reopening with the US is probably 15%.  All of those factors combined put the probability of any early border reopening fairly low, roughly 65% x 15% = 10%. We’d need a near-ideal vaccine rollout, willingness to experiment with the ban before vaccine results would be entirely clear, and an appetite to do so among the Canadian population. It’s possible that limited travel does become allowed for the sake of tourism dollars and experimentation if cases are very low by then, but a lot would need to fall into place for that to happen.
